archimate:TechnologyService.name: Health Monitoring
archimate:TechnologyService.documentation:
Health Monitoring
Refers to the continuous observation and assessment of system, application, or infrastructure performance and availability to ensure optimal operation and quickly identify issues. Key Components of Health Monitoring System Metrics:
CPU utilization, memory usage, disk I/O, and network throughput Application response times and error rates Database query performance and connection pool status Service availability and uptime percentages
Monitoring Types:
Real-time monitoring - Immediate alerts when thresholds are exceeded Trend analysis - Historical data to identify patterns and predict issues Synthetic monitoring - Automated tests that simulate user interactions Log monitoring - Analysis of application and system logs for anomalies
Health Checks:
Automated tests that verify if services are responding correctly Deep health checks that test database connectivity, external API availability Liveness probes (is the service running?) and readiness probes (is it ready to serve traffic?)
Common Tools and Approaches Cloud-Native Solutions:
AWS CloudWatch, Azure Monitor, Google Cloud Monitoring Application Performance Monitoring (APM) tools like New Relic, Datadog, AppDynamics Infrastructure monitoring with Prometheus, Grafana, Nagios
Key Benefits:
Proactive issue detection - Catch problems before they impact users Root cause analysis - Quickly identify what's causing performance issues Capacity planning - Understand resource usage patterns for scaling decisions SLA compliance - Track and report on service level agreements
